feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll feature that automatically computes daily pay deductions for employees taking unpaid leave. It calculates daily pay by dividing an employee's total salary (basic + allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month, accounting for public holidays and the applicable leave policy (calendar or working days). When an unpaid leave request is approved, the system automatically generates a corresponding pay deduction that is reflected on the payroll table. This feature ensures accurate and consistent salary reductions based on the employee's leave policy and calendar constraints.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. It defines the formula (Daily Pay = Salary Amount [Basic + Allowance] / Number of actual working days), describes the distinction between calendar days and working days leave policies, and details how public holidays are subtracted from working days to determine actual working days. The article includes an example showing that if 2 public holidays fall in a month with a 22-day working day policy, daily pay is calculated based on 20 days instead of 22.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introduces the Daily Wage Calculator feature, explaining its purpose to provide flexible and customizable daily wage calculation methods. Describes three calculation bases (calendar days, working days, custom days), the ability to select salary components, and the feature's impact on salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions. Identifies user roles (Superadmin, Payroll table managers, transaction processors) and navigation path (Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation). Highlights labor law compliance use cases for UAE and KSA.

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article documents how to update salary proration settings in the Daily Wage Calculator (DWC). It explains that Super admins can configure salary proration by selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days) via Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation. The article details the impact on first salary and end-of-service settlements, and addresses the requirement to reject existing prorated salary transactions when the payroll month is open before saving new proration settings.

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave Deduction
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request has been approved and a salary deduction must be calculated and applied to the employee's payroll.
steps: Receive and approve an unpaid leave request from an employee.
Identify the leave policy in effect (calendar days or working days).
Determine the baseline number of days (e.g., 30 calendar days or 22 working days).
Identify all public holidays falling within the month for which daily pay is being calculated.
Subtract public holidays from the baseline working days to arrive at actual working days.
Obtain the employee's total salary amount (Basic + Allowance).
Apply the formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Number of actual working days.
The system automatically creates and reflects the pay deduction on the payroll table.

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up or modifying how daily wages are calculated for payroll processing.
steps: Navigate to Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation
Select a calculation base: calendar days, working days, or custom days
Choose salary components to include in the calculation (basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only)

procedures.when_to_use: When configuring how employee salaries should be prorated based on days worked
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation
Select the required calculation basis (custom days, calendar days, or working days)
If payroll month is open with existing prorated salary transactions, reject those transactions first, then save the new proration settings

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay is calculated by dividing the employee's total salary (Basic + Allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month. ; The leave policy determines the baseline: either calendar days (e.g., 30 days) or working days (e.g., 22 days). ; Public holidays falling within the month must be deducted from the working days count to calculate actual working days. ; Pay deductions are automatically created and reflected on the payroll table only upon approval of the unpaid leave request.

Calendar days calculation uses the actual number of days in each month (e.g., 31 days in January, 28 days in February). ; Working days calculation excludes weekends and public holidays as defined in the company's public holiday calendar. ; Custom days calculation allows flexible definition of the calculation base according to company policies; most UAE and KSA companies set custom days to 30 to align with local labor law. ; Only Superadmin, Payroll table managers, or transaction processors can select and modify the calculation base.

Changes to salary proration will affect all active (unpaid) amounts in the payroll table. When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions are submitted for one or multiple employees, the Super admin must reject the transactions with prorated salaries before saving new salary proration changes

edge_cases_warnings.edge_case_or_warning: Public holidays must be carefully identified and subtracted from working days; for example, if December 2nd and 3rd are National Day holidays and the policy uses 22 working days, daily pay is calculated on 20 days (22 minus 2 public holidays), not the baseline 22 days. ; Different leave policies (calendar days vs. working days) will produce different daily pay calculations for the same salary, so the correct policy must be applied.

Monthly variation in calendar days affects daily wage calculations; months with different day counts (28, 29, 30, or 31 days) will produce different daily wage rates when using calendar days calculation base. ; Public holiday calendar accuracy is critical for working days calculations; missing or incorrectly configured public holidays will result in inaccurate daily wage calculations. ; Selection of different salary components (basic salary only vs. basic salary plus allowances) significantly impacts final daily wage rates and downstream calculations for leave encashment and unpaid leave deductions.

When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions have already been submitted for employees, Super admin must manually reject those transactions before saving new salary proration settings to avoid conflicts

Daily Wage Calculator directly impacts salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction calculations; changes to the calculation base or salary components affect all three payroll areas. ; Depends on company public holiday calendar configuration for accurate working days calculation.
